column3: We still have https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/19263 open but this should not stop us from updating here.\n\n

Ran the subtree linter locally, manually checking hashes:
```
src/secp256k1 in HEAD currently refers to tree 1b2db0573d7c4f2f90589da7886816d0db73b8c7
src/secp256k1 in HEAD was last updated in commit b9c1a7648131c5deec9704ee9acd00ec1820b9ce (tree 1b2db0573d7c4f2f90589da7886816d0db73b8c7)
src/secp256k1 in HEAD was last updated to upstream commit 8ab24e8dad9d43fc6661842149899e3cc9213b24 (tree
Looks like this bump unconditionally forces Valgrind calls on systems with Valgrind headers. Opened https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/813 to address.

@luke-jr Nothing about this PR changes behaviour with respect to valgrind (see my comments on the linked issue).\n\n[The line change at https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/19944/files#diff-54d0bb117d455c49976ee2aa20b140eaL102 is just changing it so that the standalone constant time test binary doesn't link openssl if openssl is being used by the test for comparison testing.]

ACK 894fb33f4c1b24667891f7d2aff9f486177b1173. Any Valgrind concerns will be addressed upstream, see discussion in https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/813, and if necessary, can be pulled into our tree prior to the 0.21.0 branch off. They are not a blocker for merging this PR in it's current state.

```bash
